Title: Eigenvector and eigenvalue for exponential matrix
Content: $X$ is a matrix. Let $v$ be an eigenvector of $X$ with corresponding eigenvalue $a$. Show that $v$ is also an eigenvector of $e^{X}$ with eigenvalue $e^{a}$ If $X$ is diagonalizable, then we can start writing out terms using Taylor expansion of $e^{X}$ but I can't seem to get anywhere. Thanks for the help Edit: Corrected question to read ' Let $v$ be an eigenvector of $X$' instead of ' Let $v$ be an eigenvector of $e^X$'.
AcceptedAnswer:
You don't need to assume that $X$ is diagonalisable to use the "Taylor expansion". By definition, 
$$
\exp(X) = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} X^k
$$
Also, if $Xv = av$, then $X^2v = X(Xv) = aXv = a^2v$, etc. By induction, $X^n v = a^n v$. Hence
$$
\exp(X)v 
= \left(\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} X^k \right)v 
= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} X^k v 
= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} a^k v 
= \left( \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{k!} a^k \right) v = e^a v. 
$$
